*Summary*

When viewing the permissions of a plan, a {{NullPointerException}} occurs if one of the users who has permissions on the plan does not have a full name set in their user profile.

*Steps to reproduce*
 # Configure Bamboo to use LDAP for user management
 # Create a user in LDAP who does not have the attribute that you have configured to be the user's first and last name (Note: If the user _has_ the attributes but they have no value, the problem will not arise)
 # Synchronize Bamboo with the LDAP server
 # Grant the user whom you added to LDAP permission on a plan
 # Refresh the plan permissions page

*Expected Results*

The plan permissions are displayed

*Actual Results*

A {{NullPointerException}} occurs with a stack trace similar to the following:
{code:java}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.util.Comparator.lambda$comparing$77a9974f$1(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.TimSort.countRunAndMakeAscending(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.TimSort.sort(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.Arrays.sort(Unknown Source)

	at java.util.stream.SortedOps$RefSortingSink.end(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.stream.Sink$ChainedReference.end(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(Unknown Source)

By design it is not possible to create users without a full name in Bamboo when using Bamboo's built-in user database. However, if the backend database is modified manually and the column {{FULLNAME}} for the user's record in the {{USERS}} table has a {{NULL}} value, the problem also arises.

h3. Problem Definition
NAS / NFS for {{<bamboo-home>}} is common however our JMS processing doesn't perform well when the jms-store is not on fast, low-latency, local storage.

It would be great to have a property to to change the location of the jms-store so that all of {{<bamboo-home>}} can exist on the NAS / NFS, with the exception of the jms-store.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Implement a property that can be configured in the {{<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}} to override the default path for the jms-store.
 
h3. Workaround 
# Point {{<bamboo-home>}} at local storage in {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-init.properties}}
# You will need to move all files and subdirectories that are not covered by the below properties to the local storage location.
# Modify each individual path within {{<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}} and point it at the NAS / NFS:
{code}
<property name="bamboo.artifacts.directory">${bambooHome}/artifacts</property>
<property name="bamboo.config.directory">${bambooHome}/xml-data/configuration</property>
<property name="bamboo.project.directory">${bambooHome}/xml-data/builds</property>
<property name="bamboo.repository.logs.directory">${bambooHome}/xml-data/repository-specs</property>
<property name="buildWorkingDir">${bambooHome}/xml-data/build-dir</property>
<property name="daily.backup.dir">${bambooHome}/backups</property>
<property name="webwork.multipart.saveDir">${bambooHome}/temp</property>
{code}

h6. Notes
The _largest_ directories are usually {{bamboo.artifacts.directory}}, {{bamboo.project.directory}}, {{buildWorkingDir}} and {{daily.backup.dir}}.

It is recommended to keep the {{lucene.index.dir}} on local storage too:
{code}
<property name="lucene.index.dir">${bambooHome}/index</property>
{code}

h3. Summary
In some projects, developers expect of a branch to have different build options or paths. Since Tasks are only defined at plan level, this breaks the builds of branches. 

h3. Accepted Solution
- Have the possibility to share, in a same repository, Specs and the actual project
- For every commit (push) in a branch, the plan will be redefined (by Specs), having the chance to change tasks (at branch level). 

In this way, master will continue using the normal flow, and branches will build in their own way. In this way there is no risk of branches failing when there is a design (or structural) change in the code.
fields.summary: Have a shared repository between Specs and the actual project, and allow Specs branching.

Currently we cache the agent classpath in a file {{jarFromResource#####.jar}} within {{<bamboo-install>/temp}} ({{java.io.tmpdir}}). 

This same directory is prone to file build up (possibly due to local agents and maven builds) and on occasion has been cleaned manually by Bamboo Administrators.

Once this file is removed:
* Agents will no longer be able to connect / reconnect
* The agent install JAR cannot be downloaded

It cannot be regenerated without restarting Bamboo 

h3. Expected results
* Bamboo regenerates the file if it no longer exists.
or
* Bamboo generates this file within {{<bamboo-home>/caches}} or {{<bamboo-home>/temp}} instead to reduce the chances of it being mistakingly removed.

h3. Summary

Once you add a "Source code checkout" task to the deployment plan, the relationship between the linked repository and the deployment plan will be persisted even if the task is deleted. 

If you try to delete the linked repository, the warning message will show that the repository is being used by the deployment.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a "Source code checkout" task to the deployment plan selecting one of the current available linked repositories
# Delete the "Source code checkout" task
# Go to linked repositories and try to delete the repo used in the first step.

h3. Expected Results
The "Remove repository" confirmation screen should not list this deployment plan in Environment section.

h3. Actual Results
The "Remove repository" confirmation screen will warn that the repository is still being used by the deployment.

The relationship will only be overwritten if a new "Source code checkout" task is added using a different repository.

h3.Workaround
This is just a cosmetic issue. If the repository is not being used by the deployment you can safely delete it.
fields.summary: Linked Repositories relationship with environments is not updated after deleting the "Source code checkout" task

fields.description:
h6.Problem Description:
Consider a scenario where your Bamboo is located at Geo-Location-1 and there are 4 agents located at Geo-Location-1, Geo-Location-2, Geo-Location-3, Geo-Location-4 respectively.

In this case, the majority of the time only one agent is used i.e., the agent on the Geo-Location-1 which is close to the Bamboo server. This is because of the latency since this agents always responds first it the utilized the most. This could be problematic when you have other tasks to do on the same Geo-Location-1 machine where your agent is located. 

h6.Suggested Solution:
Configure Bamboo to have some mechanism to evenly distribute the jobs to the remote agents. 

h6.Workaround:
Use the Custom Capability and requirements.
Assign custom capability to the agents and the custom requirements to the build plans based on the Geolocation. 

For example:

* Let's say your developers in Singapore work on PlanA, PlanB, PlanC
* We will go to these plans and add a custom requirement "SGPLANS" to it.
* Then we will go to the agent's configurations and add the same to their requirement as custom - "SGPLANS"
* This way Singapore based plans will be run by the Singapore agents,
_We could follow this for other geo's as well._
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to have even distribution of jobs to the remote agents

h3. Problem Definition
There is no option in YAML Specs to clean the working directory after execution of a build.
However, it is possible to do this from the Bamboo UI by choosing "Clean working directory after each build" option under *Plan configuration -> Miscellaneous* tab.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a Specs option to clean the working directory after the build (similar to the option we set in the Bamboo UI)

h3. Why this is important
Some builds need clean working directory  before each build.

h3. Workaround 
One will have to start their definition with script task like below to have a clean working directory:

{noformat}
stages:
  - jobs:
      - scripts:
          - rm -rf ${bamboo.build.working.directory}
          - #your scripts here
{noformat}
However, having this in the script might delete the source code or the artifacts.
fields.summary: Option to clean working directory in YAML

If a Bamboo remote agent fails in the midst of a Job that had been using a docker environment then we will see the docker process spawned by Bamboo remaining across restarts of the agent.

If docker is used by Bamboo in a Job then Bamboo will spawn a docker container running 
"tail -f /dev/null". Thus holding the container active to be used by the Job.
This docker instance would normally be cleaned up and removed during the Docker cleanup task in the job.

If the remote agent aborts whilst before the Docker cleanup task is executed these processes persist.

{noformat}
$ docker ps
CONTAINER ID IMAGE COMMAND CREATED STATUS PORTS NAMES
5c1ab003564f xxxxx:1.0 "tail -f /dev/null" 4 days ago Up 4 days c8c1332b-2a06-4cc1-9a70-68d79c8202b881887236
1a144aded739 xxxxx:1.0 "tail -f /dev/null" 4 days ago Up 4 days 586e5563-ffa8-421c-b323-6bec9eccfaeb81887236
{noformat}

This enhancement request is for the Bamboo agent to maintain some persistent knowledge about the processes, docker instances, that it has spawned and clean these up when it restarts, as necessary.
fields.summary: Bamboo remote agent should clean up after itself.

fields.description:
When using flow-bin, as an example, multiple child processes are spawned during the build that do not get cleaned up when complete. While, in the case of flow-bin, this is a [reported bug|https://github.com/flowtype/flow-bin/issues/88] (wish an [open pull request|https://github.com/flowtype/flow-bin/pull/89] for a fix), the same behavior can be seen with anything that does not clean up after itself.

In the use case that spawned this request, our customer provides Bamboo as a service to their customers and they can opt to use tools such as flow-bin that then leave child processes behind and eventually cuz the agent to run out of memory an crash. It would be preferred if there was a cleanup process to ensure that there are not errant child processes left to consume resources.

---

This issue cloned from https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-11544 where this functionality was added to the UI. There is now a request for a method in the branch creation API endpoint to allow for this same functionality through the REST API. 

{panel:title=Original Description}
The new branch functionality shows great promise.  But, and there's always a but, it doesn't handle plans with multiple source repositories.  

For an example setup, I have code stored in the following svn locations:

/svn/libraries/core/trunk
/svn/libraries/widget-creator/trunk
/svn/applications/magic-8-ball/trunk

To create a clean build of the magic-8-ball application, I need to check out all three in order and build them.  If I want to branch the magic-8-ball application for release and have it depend on specific versions of its libraries, the source directories might be:

/svn/libraries/core/branches/3.14
/svn/libraries/widget-creator/branches/12345
/svn/applications/magic-8-ball/branches/1.2

From a functional perspective, each of the source repositories in a plan needs to be able to have a separate source repository path when building a given branch.  This path for the default build, this other path when building the '1.2' branch etc.

On the UI side when configuring a Bamboo Branch, the current location for specifying a different source repository when building for a branch is partially non-intuitive.  To my mind, especially if Bamboo's concept of Branch builds becomes more central to Bamboo's operation, having the different source repositories for Branches as additional options in the Configuration -> Source Repositories -> Edit Source Repository tab would make more sense.  For Branch (pulldown) use [this] repository information with [x] same password or different password etc.  I really like the idea of not having to retype the same repository password multiple times.
{panel}
fields.summary: Rest API Method for branching with multiple source repositories

h3. Problem Definition
Traffic between the Bamboo Server and Elastic agents is tunneled. HTTP traffic from the Elastic Agent arrives on the Bamboo Server via the tunnel and it is routed by the tunnel client to the Base URL ({{Bamboo Administration >> Overview >> General Configuration >> Base URL}}) of the Bamboo Server. 

If the Base URL of the instance cannot be reached from the Bamboo Server (e.g. the address is a load balancer or reverse proxy and the Bamboo Server has no outbound access), the HTTP connection cannot be established. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Programmatically add a separate Tomcat HTTP connector for receiving HTTP traffic from the tunnel client that binds to loopback. Prioritize connection attempts as follows:
# Value of {{bamboo.ec2.agent.endpoint}} override argument
# New HTTP connector
# Fallback to Base URL

* See the Resolution section of: [Elastic agents remain in Pending and do not connect|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/elastic-agents-remain-in-pending-and-do-not-connect-after-upgrading-bamboo-859480838.html]

h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo branch detection for SVN only works for /branches and /branch. Using tags within a path creates severe problems, as tags aren't really branches.

*Bamboo tries to perform branch detection, finds no branch matching ".../tags/...", assumes it has already been deleted and marks the related plan branch for expiry in <number configured> days, where (unwished) plan deletion takes place.*

h3. How to provoke the Issue

* Selecting the "Branches" tab within "Plan configuration"
* Clicking button "Create plan branch"
* Clicking button "Create plan branch manually"
* Setting the "VCS branch name" field to ".../tags/..." matching the full path to that tag in the SVN repository

h3. Suggested Solution

* Add the ability to select SVN tags for build steps, similar to what Bamboo performs correctly for /branches and /branch, thus add /tags and /tag treatment
* Make this work with SVN repositories originally hosting these tags

h3. Workaround 

# Whenever Bamboo user manually create a plan branch for a tag, he / she will need to +manually disable expiry for that plan branch+ at: *Branch Configuration > Branch Details > Clean up plan branch automatically*
# Bamboo user could also clone his / her plan and +have a separate plan just for tags+: *Plan Configuration > Branches > Manually define branch detection path* and set a path of ".../tags/..." (so it will no longer service /branches)
# Alternatively, same idea as item above, but differently configured, namely: *Plan Configurations > Repositories > click "svn repository" > expand "Branch detection options" > Manually define branch detection path*
fields.summary: Ability to correctly use SVN repository tags for branch plan

h3. Summary
Removing an agent while builds are queued can cause the Build Activity dashboard to fail until the build queue depletes. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan
# Add a script task with sleep 600;
# Have one local agent
# Set concurrent builds limit to 3
# Start one build of the plan (it'll go to the local agent and keep it busy -- this step could be superfluous)
# Connect a new remote agent
# Have the following tabs open:
#* {{Build > Build Activity}}
#* {{Bamboo Overview > Agents}}
#* {{Plan configuration}} for the plan (so you can fire off some more builds), or use REST API to queue them: {{$BAMBOO_URL/rest/api/latest/queue/$PLAN_KEY}}
# Start two more builds in quick succession
# *Quickly* go to the Agents tab and delete the remote agent before it registers as currently building (validation will stop you removing it otherwise)
# Switch to the Build Activity tab, you'll see the {{NullPointerException}} in the logs but the impact won't necessarily be evident until the page is refreshed.
# Now the build activity dashboard won't recover till the build queue depletes.

h3. Expected Results
The build activity dashboard is resilient when an agent is deleted.

h3. Summary
When no {{hibernate.c3p0.max_size}} is defined in {{<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}} (e.g. if a Tomcat JDBC Datasource is being used instead) then the Bamboo plan cache will be initialized with only a single thread. This can cause significant delays in start-up of Bamboo.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure a Tomcat JDBC Datasource
# Remove {{hibernate.c3p0.max_size}} from {{<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml}}
# Start Bamboo

h3. Expected Results
Plan cache is initialized thread count equal to available processors.

h3. Actual Results
Plan cache is initialized with 1 thread:
{noformat}
2018-04-22 13:07:10,053 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [ImmutablePlanCacheServiceImpl] Initialising plan cache with 1 threads.
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
# Stop Bambo
# Edit your {{<bamboo-install>/bin/setenv.sh}} (or equivalent) and add the below. Set the value to the amount of CPU processors available (aka the result of {{nproc --all}})
{code}
: ${JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS:="-Datlassian.bamboo.plan.cache.loading.threads=8"}
{code}
#* [Configuring your system properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-your-system-properties-289277345.html]
# Start Bamboo
fields.summary: Bamboo plan cache is initialized with only 1 thread when hibernate.c3p0.max_size is undefined

h3. Problem Definition
Most of the configuration details and user data are located in Bamboo home, but some very common adjustments are also located in the Bamboo installation folder like tomcat details, JVM arguments, and SSO authenticator.

The upgrade process requires renewing the Bamboo installation folder and it is common that some of these configurations are not replicated to the new installation causing unexpected issues.

h3. Suggested Solution
Bamboo could store such data in the Bamboo home directory avoiding the need to manually migrate such configuration.
fields.summary: Migrate installation config to home directory (simplifying the upgrade process)

h3. Summary
Server status REST API loops continuously even though the session expire

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log into Bamboo from browser.
# Remove Anonymous user permission from Global Permission
# Restart Bamboo server.

h3. Expected Results
 * /rest/api/latest/server will stop after receiving error

h3. Actual Results
* /rest/api/latest/server receive 401 error and keep on looping for every 30 seconds

h3. Notes
* Use Google Chrome Developer Tools Network tab to check the network traffic
* User may not notice the session timeout
* The problem will also happen when browser session timeout (without restarting Bamboo server)
* This problem will produce a huge amount of 401 errors in Tomcat access log - the security team will perceive this as an attack

h3. Workaround
# Shutdown Bamboo
# Edit the file {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/scripts/serverstate.js}} to add "doPoll = false" to the following line:
{noformat}
                error: function (request, textStatus, errorThrown) {
                    updateStatus({state: BAMBOO.ADMIN.STATUS_ERROR}, textStatus + ": " + errorThrown);
                    doPoll = false;
                }
{noformat}
# Restart Bamboo
# User may need to restart browser due to browser cache
fields.summary: server status loops even when error returned by server

[Disabling or deleting a plan|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0601/disabling-or-deleting-a-plan-935580976.html] documentation states:
 * The ['Admin' global permission|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo0601/granting-global-permissions-to-users-or-groups-935581791.html] is required to delete a plan.

However, after changes to the permission structure in Bamboo, this is no longer accurate. Plan permission can be set more granularly and users can be given "Admin" priveledges at the plan level. The documentation needs to be updated to reflect this.

Suggested Edit: “The ‘Admin' global permission is required to delete a plan.” should read similar to “Users with the ‘Admin’ global permission and users with the ‘Admin’ permission set at the plan level can delete plans.”
